With its excellent cast, great production values, topical social commentary and a promising source material, it aspires to be nominated for as much awards as possible. However, it ultimately fails in its ambitions and becomes a failed Oscar bait because of its terrible editing, uneven tone, frustrating pace, convoluted and incoherent narrative, underdeveloped characters and nonsensical plot twists. The assumption that the Iran-Contra scandal comes up during ANY current political dinner conversations these days is the Achilles heel that this Saga can point to as the instigator for its dastardly demise. That and some serious continuity faux-pas that made what would otherwise have been a enchantingly cerebral narrative, seem more opaque and incomprehensible than should be considered tolerable. I would happily watch the directors cut of this enterprise just to see how much of the initial vision was left on the cutting-room floor the first time around. A solid story-line, a more than adequate cast,  perfectly acceptable location and cinematography, a quirky and thought-provoking score, and a hitherto talented director. Yet here we are. Only a directors cut could possibly redeem this  botched rendition of what is clearly an important tale that ought to be widely retold, if only to prevent it from all happening again.

In short beside great cinematography this movie fails in every departement.

Great noir can sneak up on you with an indirect, disingenuousness subverting commercial expectation.  Patience allows Anne Hathaway, Rosie Perez, Ben Affleck, Edi Gathegi to perform and triumph, over a geographically complex, shadowy & tragic tale.  The Last Thing He Wanted sports an international criminalia assisting Americas brutal empire in whitewashing with gore, lies, terror, and profiteering the flag-waving Reagan years by squashing reporters.  Couldn't be more current.  The addled reviews likely reflect the youth and ignorance of the reviewers to the Reagan Era of regulatory capture, redistribution of wealth, subversive wars of terror, and mass disinformation.  A CULTURE OF TERROR or MANUFACTURING CONSENT by Chomsky, BLOOD ON THE TRACK BY S. Brian Wilson would ground reviewers and audiences in the subtextualized events stirring "plot".   It may be the fatuous fleet of male reviewers are insensitive to the a decentered, Amerocritical, female directors, female stars and female writers storytelling.  I tried, late at night, not to watch this splendid work, and failed.  Like all art, it dragged me into its remarkable horrors, with pitty, patience, and love.  Bless these artists for committing to evoke truth of a denied history.

(Has spoilers) This was like what you'd feel if you were flushed down the toilet. You go through multiple twists and turns , hoping that there is a reprieve at the end, but then you end up in mother of all sh*t hole. Who in their sane mind would write (actually modify) the script to make Treat kill Helena? He just had a very nice romantic night with her (sunset, sweet talk, sex..) and then turns around and shoots her the next day with apparently no provocation and making you think that it was pre-meditated? if it was pre-meditated he could have killed her the first night itself when they met at the bar. This is why the original author of the book apparently had an ending where an assassin shoots Treat and Helena gets killed in the cross fire. Otherwise, it just leaves the audience with that shocker of  "What the F just happened!". I mean, movies can have sad endings, its ok, but they have to be realistic too. This was like the movie script writer wanted to add a mother of all twists, and blew it up in the process. The directors and producers must be extra careful for Satan Ex Machinas like this. If a book is a flop, nobody loses anything. Ah, well, the author probably lost coupla hours and the publisher a bunch of paper price, but not anything like a movie. In fact this movie looked like it was really shot in all those exotic locations too, instead of a set. So yes, the producer really would have been punched in the stomach. Am sorry man. The actors did a good job though.  Edi Gathegi especially. I have seen him in the series Blacklist as a very dangerous force to be reckoned with and boy does he not do a good job. But yeah, great talent wasted by poor writing, which even leaves you with so many unanswered qns. Why was Paul killed? Why was max epperson (or bob weir or whatever his name is) a friend of Dick but still wants to kill him (or her daughter). I don't know man. Gives you a high and dry feeling like the girl came home with you after the first date, but then walked out just before getting to bed. And who is he in "the last thing he wanted?" Dick? Oh please. The movie really should have been "the last thing she wanted" to go with the narrative. The journalist who keeps asking who runs all this, and then realizes it was she herself or something like that. But yeah guys, careful with this movie...stay safe from two things, corona and this movie. LOL

Why does she run from people protecting her? Why does she sleep with that other character? Why does she have to pretend to work for someone else, and why does it matter that we see the boyfriend skinny dipping in the pool? Is Ben Affleck CIA, State Dept... aspiring president? What is that delicious dessert he was eating with Sec of State Schultz? How can Ben Affleck teleport between DC and Central America instantaneously? How is he able to find Anne Hathaway after only about ten seconds when other people have failed to catch her for days? Finally â€” which Latin American substances were the writers and editors on, since maybe that's why it's so disjointed? Can I now purchase this substance in my home state ( ha ha)?

The story is gripping on paper, but not on film. The twists and turns in Elena's story might have room to breathe in novel form, but packed into two hours, they feel rushed, and the motives are incomprehensible. Maybe Elena's alternating dislike of and devotion to carrying out her father's last job would make more sense if their relationship was a bigger story focus, but Dafoe exits the picture early. So maybe the film is more about her search for the truth? Except the story's journalistic aspect is also only addressed in fits, in favor of spending more time building up its spy/thriller side.

This joke has been made a thousand times but The Last Thing He Wanted perfectly resembles how I feel about this movie. It was the last thing I wanted to see. There is so much that is wrong with this film. Whenever I watch a movie for the first time, I pay full attention to it so that I don't miss any details. After watching this, I thought, "What?". I don't understand what this movie was about or what happened. Its plot is so convoluted and confusing that I honestly can't tell you what happened. The film has little to no structure to it. Scenes just happen and then they go on to another unrelated scene. Since I couldn't understand what was happening, I was incredibly bored. This is one of the most boring films I have ever seen. None of the characters are interesting or developed in the slightest. I like Ben Affleck, Anne Hathaway, and Willem Dafoe but I hated their characters. They are all unlikeable and don't have any motivation for what they do. Anne Hathway's character doesn't like her father at all and yet she decides to take over his job? It made no sense. Their performances weren't that great either. Willem Dafoe was fine and his performance was the only aspect I found above average but Affleck and Hathaway were pretty bad. Hathaway sounded like a robot the entire film and Affleck who has top billing was only in the film for 15 minutes. He contributed almost nothing to the film. The other actors did a pretty poor job and were very forgettable. I honestly forgot that Toby Jones was in the film until I started writing this. The script they were given was particularly awful. The dialogue was poorly written and shallow which hampered everyone's performance. The cinematography was fine. It wasn't special but it wasn't bad. The editing was particularly annoying though. It would cut randomly during scenes which threw off the focus of it. At other points, the editing would cut so rapidly and quickly that it was hard to tell what was going on. Overall, The Last Thing He Wanted is a convoluted, confusing, and boring film with a poor script, bad characters, and obnoxious editing.

I'm not sure if this is trying to be an expose or what. Apart from the general story line being one of certain question, you can't just walk up to an operation like this and insert yourself in the mix without being reduced to dust before your little master plan even begins. There's a reason why all of this is still happening, and to some degree, you see that in the film by the end, which is both predictable and simultaneously idiotic. All they had to do to get at least a 3 star rating from me is remove the daughter from the movie. She adds absolutely nothing while existing as the primary reason why this movie would never have happened. Dying dad wants you to uncover a massive arms ring? First thing you say is - uh, no? I have a kid. Even if I don't die out there, someone will send people after her. No mention per say, unless I was too bored to notice. So from the get go it is a masterpiece of foolishness in writing and execution. Hey, give it a go if you want to try to see something we're all not seeing. It has a good cast and good production value. It's just not a good movie.

If you're able to make it past the muddied first thirty minutes you'll discover a somewhat interesting story to watch... even if it is impossible to follow. With the many story, editing, and cinematography issues, Anne Hathaway was able to defy the odds and give a somewhat convincing performance.

So many really good actors, a promising storyline, and a cracking 1st 20 minutes, and then it just goes completely to custard. I think Ben Affleck is a hugely underrated actor, but this is Ben at his absolute wooden worst. Hathaway goes from looking harried and stressed (as you would in a war zone) to just completely confused - maybe by the plot?
